docs.lead_paragraph: Richard Branson's Virgin Group said today that it would take on British insurers with new low-cost life and health insurance products sold directly by telephone. For years, the life insurance industry in Britain has been a bastion of commission-seeking middlemen, and the big insurers have only recently started experimenting with direct sales. A highly successful effort by the insurance arm of the Royal Bank of Scotland, Direct Line, sells insurance over the phone, but has not yet had the impact in life insurance as it has in the auto insurance market.

headline.main: Insurance by Phone Is Offered in Britain

docs.lead_paragraph: In what could be a harbinger of other such transactions, a deal was completed today creating one of the country's largest charitable foundations as well as a big health care company that is likely to pursue numerous acquisitions as it grows. A number of Blue Cross health care organizations across the country have struggled in recent years to balance their obligation to provide programs for the poor, as well as benefits to the states that have granted them tax advantages, with their need to raise capital to expand in the increasingly competitive health care market.

headline.main: A Deal by Wellpoint Creates a Health Provider and Two Charities

docs.lead_paragraph: After the sit-in, picketing and demonstrations, after the disruptions at commencement and weeks without paychecks, the 41-day-old strike at Barnard College has left the school's administration and the 150 striking clerical workers badly bruised, but hardly closer to a settlement. What started as a polite dispute over whether the workers would have to help pay for their health insurance premiums has evolved into a test of wills in which neither side appears willing to reach out to the other. There have been no negotiations for almost six weeks, and no new ones are scheduled.

headline.main: Test of Wills in Strike by Barnard Clerical Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: The peculiar publishing tale of Noah Gordon ends happily, with millions of devoted readers, wealth and prizes, and gala dinners in his honor. But it leaves hanging a great book-world mystery, for though Mr. Gordon is an American who writes his novels in America, mainly about American themes, the vast majority of those honors and dinners and millions of readers are foreign.

headline.main: Best-Selling Author, but Not at Home

docs.lead_paragraph: Chiropractors are again pressuring the New York State Legislature to give them through the political process what they could never achieve in the marketplace. They have pushed a bill through the Senate that would require health plans in the state to cover unlimited chiropractic services. The bill, which the Assembly could take up at any time, would amount to a full-employment act for chiropractors, but a health-care tax on everyone else -- forcing up insurance premiums to offset increased use of often unnecessary treatments. Chiropractic services can be useful for acute low-back pain. But even for this ailment, studies show that the same service is equally well administered, at lower cost, by primary-care practitioners. Under the bill, every group policy in the state would have to raise premiums in order to cover chiropractic treatment of unproved value, for example of chronic low-back pain or back pain due to complications like sciatic nerve problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: The credibility of the American Association of Retired Persons will be at stake if the organization proceeds with efforts to license its name to managed care plans for a fee. The 33 million-member organization is a powerful lobbying group that tries to sway Congress on issues important to the elderly and provides services that are supposed to benefit its members. But A.A.R.P. also earns substantial income -- amounting to about 40 percent of its $345 million budget -- by charging fees for endorsing selected auto, health and homeowner insurance policies. That raises a potential conflict of interest because the policies that might be best for the elderly are not always the policies that are best for the bank account of the A.A.R.P. The A.A.R.P. collects about $100 million a year from the Prudential Insurance Company of America for putting A.A.R.P.'s seal of approval on Prudential insurance policies -- primarily Medigap plans, which pay some of the costs Medicare does not cover. But that income, which is based on the premiums Prudential collects, is eroding as healthier A.A.R.P. members have begun to enroll in managed Medicare plans, which include some Medigap benefits, or to buy less expensive Medigap policies from insurers that, unlike Prudential, offer discounts to younger applicants. So A.A.R.P. plans to recoup the lost income by selling its endorsements to managed Medicare plans as well.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN Richmond, a man who was a volunteer with the Red Cross drove a woman to a medical appointment. In Oregon, two men accompanied a Boy Scout troop on a camping trip. Though the three men were unpaid workers, giving their time for what they considered good causes, they were all eventually sued after someone in their care was injured in an accident. The suit against the Red Cross volunteer was dismissed. But a jury in Portland, Ore., ruled that the Scout leaders, Howard J. Ryburn and Craig A. Nordling, were negligent when a boy was paralyzed during a touch football game on the 1991 camping trip, and the two men were hit with a $7 million judgment in 1994. Though the Boy Scouts and its insurance paid the judgment and the legal costs for both men, Mr. Ryburn, who is 28, said he would not be a volunteer for a while.

headline.main: Doing Good May Be No Shield When Bad Happens

docs.lead_paragraph: TO help keep more elderly people on Long Island, the Town of North Hempstead is planning a "life care community" in Port Washington. The center would be the first of its type in Nassau County. Life-care plans are like insurance policies. They cover housing, services, amenities and health care, including long-term care, at one site.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Karen Schuman began suffering from severe insomnia last year, she tried to keep it in perspective. "I'd say: 'It's not cancer. God forbid, it's not AIDS,' " she recalled. Yet night after night of not sleeping eventually wore her down. "After a while, you fear going to bed," said Mrs. Schuman, a 54-year-old elementary-school teacher in East Brunswick. On top of the nightly panic, she felt weak and ill; she lost her appetite and her patience. Friends' advice was worse than useless: "What do you mean?" they would tell her. "Just empty your mind of everything."

headline.main: Help With Sleep Problems, From Clinics to the Internet
